item.title: Fully-jabbed from EU and US could avoid quarantine
item.description: Senior cabinet ministers are due to discuss the move for arrivals to England in a meeting on Wednesday.

item.title: Chronic health issues for third in late 40s - study
item.description: About one in three has problems such as high blood pressure and mental ill health, a study suggests.

item.title: Electric car charging prices 'must be fair' say MPs
item.description: Consumers should not have to pay excessive prices to use public car charging, MPs say.

item.title: Let more Afghan interpreters resettle in UK, say ex-military chiefs
item.description: More Afghans who worked for British forces should be allowed to resettle in the UK, former military chiefs say.

item.title: Covid: Sydney extends lockdown as other Australian cities reopen
item.description: Infections in Australia's largest city remain stubbornly high, despite five weeks of restrictions.

item.title: Capitol riot: Policeman tells 6 January hearing he feared he would die
item.description: Officers on duty when Trump supporters stormed the US Capitol give tearful testimony at an inquiry.

item.title: 'Transformative' disability plan to be unveiled
item.description: A £1.6bn strategy aimed at improving the lives of disabled people is to be set out by the government.

item.title: Biles praised for prioritising her mental health
item.description: American gymnast Simone Biles is praised for prioritising "mental wellness over all else" after pulling out of the Olympic women's team final.

item.title: Covid-19: CDC brings back indoor mask guidance for virus hot spots
item.description: In states seeing surges, US health officials again recommend masking for all - including at schools.

item.title: Joey Jordison: Slipknot founding drummer dies aged 46
item.description: Jordison was a member of the mask-wearing heavy metal band and also performed with the likes of Metallica.

item.title: Toy giant Mattel warns of higher prices as costs rise
item.description: The Barbie maker's comments as it announced better than expected quarterly sales.

item.title: Eagle eyes spot kestrel chicks in jet plane exhaust
item.description: The young birds "lucky to be alive" after found hiding in exhaust of an Airbus plane during repairs.

item.title: The Papers: UK 'reopens to world' and 'betrayed' kids in care
item.description: A quarantine waiver for EU and US travellers and a cover-up in social care lead the front pages.

item.title: Lebanon’s descent into darkness
item.description: The country's economic crisis has forced some families to move into refugee camps to survive.

item.title: Roma student: 'My only goal is to finish school'
item.description: How one school in Croatia is working to improve education opportunities for Roma children like Kristina.

item.title: Gilgamesh tablet: US authorities take ownership of artefact
item.description: The Gilgamesh Dream Tablet was imported illegally into the US before being bought by Hobby Lobby.

item.title: US sells unique Wu-Tang Clan album seized from 'pharma bro' Martin Shkreli
item.description: The album was handed over as part of a $7.4m deal with a notorious former drug firm executive.

item.title: Scottish boy plucked from obscurity stars in Indian film Mimi on Netflix
item.description: Three-year-old Jacob Smith of Aberdeen was plucked from obscurity on holiday and cast with Kriti Sanon in Mimi.

item.title: Dad builds robotic exoskeleton to help son walk
item.description: The French robotics engineer says he was inspired to build the suit after his son asked him to.

item.title: Coronavirus: Four numbers that reveal the real trends
item.description: Does a week of falling case numbers mean we're close to the end?

item.title: Zimbabwean with football dreams to be kicked out of UK
item.description: Christopher Arundell grew up in the UK but after doing time in jail is being deported to Zimbabwe.

item.title: Crime: Boris Johnson's claims checked
item.description: A look at the prime minister's claims about crime statistics, police numbers and funding.

item.title: What happens to British ships when satellites don't work?
item.description: The Royal Navy and merchant fleet have no back-up if navigation systems are disrupted, experts warn.

item.title: 'Luxury' race will be among most expensive on earth
item.description: A four-day ultramarathon covering 120 miles on the west coast of Scotland will cost £15,499 to enter.

item.title: The black immigrant who challenged US segregation - nearly 190 years ago
item.description: A black Brazilian immigrant was the first person in US history to challenge segregation in a courtroom

item.title: CEO Secrets: The son who hired his father and sister
item.description: Ross Testa explains why he hired his sister and then his father for his social media business.

item.title: Mapping the advance of the Taliban in Afghanistan
item.description: Maps of Afghanistan show who controls districts in fighting between the government and Taliban forces.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Tom Dean & Duncan Scott lead Team GB to 4x200m freestyle relay gold
item.description: Tom Dean and Duncan Scott lead Team GB to a brilliant 4x200m freestyle relay gold with a dominant display alongside Matthew Richards and James Guy.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Team GB claim silver in men's quadruple sculls final
item.description: Team GB claim their first ever Olympic medal in the men's quadruple sculls with silver at Tokyo 2020.

item.title: Who could be this season's breakout Premier League star?
item.description: BBC Sport selects nine players who could make a genuine impact on the Premier League next season.

item.title: Man Utd agree to sign Varane for initial £34m fee
item.description: Manchester United confirm they have reached an agreement to sign France defender Raphael Varane from Real Madrid.

item.title: Great Britain win team dressage bronze as Dujardin equals British medal record
item.description: Charlotte Dujardin equals the most number of Olympic medals won by a British woman by claiming team dressage bronze in Tokyo.

item.title: Bairstow powers Fire to win over Brave in men's Hundred
item.description: Jonny Bairstow's 72 from 39 balls sets up a second win for Welsh Fire as they overcome Southern Brave

item.title: Sign up for the BBC Sport app
item.description: With latest scores and headlines sent straight to your device, personalisation and much more, ensure you have a great sporting life with BBC Sport.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Great Britain win emphatic gold in 4x200m freestyle relay
item.description: Great Britain's men secure another gold in the Olympic pool with a dominant victory in the 4x200m freestyle relay in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Great Britain rowers win silver in men's quadruple sculls
item.description: Britain's rowers win their first Olympic medal in the men's quadruple sculls as Harry Leask, Angus Groom, Tom Barras and Jack Beaumont claim silver at Tokyo 2020.

item.title: Watch: 'There's going to be a crash!'
item.description: Team GB miss out on a medal in the men's four final after some dramatic steering issues almost cause a crash at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Ariarne Titmus claims second gold in women's 200m freestyle
item.description: Ariarne Titmus wins her latest battle with five-time Olympic gold medallist Katie Ledecky and sets a Games record in the women's 200m freestyle.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Great Britain women's hockey team beat India
item.description: Great Britain women's hockey team continue the defence of their Olympic title with a convincing 4-1 win against India in pool A.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Take a tour of the incredible venues
item.description: They range from an arena built by a father and son, to a legendary home of Japanese martial arts.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: German gymnasts' full-body suits inspire other athletes
item.description: British-Jamaican gymnast Danusia Francis believes athletes should have a choice over their outfits.

item.title: What's happening on Wednesday?
item.description: Want to know what's happening when in Tokyo? Check out our comprehensive guide to all the action in Japan.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics medals table
item.description: Medals table for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid rules: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Fully jabbed adults don't have to self-isolate after visiting amber-list countries - except France.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate, which workers are exempt and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: A small number of named employees in key sectors will be exempt from some rules

item.title: 'Covid passports': How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both jabs?
item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England will have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: New research links as many as 200 different symptoms to the condition.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but the government has criticised take-up among young people.

item.title: The EU vaccine 'passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: An EU vaccine "passport" is being introduced, enabling holders to prove they have been jabbed.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as more than 46 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the NHS test-and-trace system and app work?
item.description: The contact tracing app could be changed to make it less sensitive, so it sends fewer alerts.

item.title: Care homes worst hit by Covid – search the data
item.description: Figures from Care Quality Commission lay out the pandemic's 'devastating impact' on care homes in England.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and how will Covid affect them?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics have begun, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Vaccine experts recommend that a limited group of children should be offered Covid jabs ahead of winter.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.
